Express Steamers leave Alexandria every Wednesday at 4 p.m. for PIRAEUS, SMYRNA, MITYLENE, and CONSTANTINOPLE, in connection with Orient Express train-de-luxe for Vienna, Paris, and London.

Fast steamers leave Alexandria every Saturday at 4 p.m., and Port Said every Sunday at 6 p.m., for JAFFA (for Jerusalem), CAIFFA (for Nazareth), BEYROUT (for Damascus), TRIPOLI, ALEXANDRETTA, MESSINA, continuing in alternate weeks to LARNACA and LIMASSOL (Cyprus).

div.head: DOES PAN-ISLAMISM EXIST?
div.p: In discussing the Pan-Islamic bogey, which the Head season revived from a long slumber, the Constantinople correspondent of the "Tribune remarks that the evidence brought forward in support of the contention that "Yildiz Palace has become the head centre of a great organization which aims at embracing the whole Mussulman world, and has certainly succeeded in spreading its ramifications bver a great part of it" utterly fails to support it

The strongest evidence adduced," he says is derived from recent occurrences in Egypt. What it amounts to is this: that Egypt having been taken out of the control of Turkey, the ulema of that country and the Moslem population generally were urged, both on the occasion of the naval demonstrations regarding Tabah and the unfortunate 1 incident at Denishwai, to show their dis
satisfaction with British interference in Egypt, and that to a certain extent they showed such digestisfaction. But there is no necessary connexion between such display and a PanIslamic movement.

"Everyone can readily understand that the substitution of British for Turkish control in Egypt gave rise to very great irritation among the Turkish official class, both here and in Egypt. It could not have been otherwise. Recall the circumstances. Egypt was by far the largest and the most important of the tributary states under Turkish rule. When England first determined to land troops in Egypt, the Sultan was invited to send his troops and to make the occupation a, joint one. For reasons well known he refused, and, to the astonishment of Yildiz, British troops entered alone. Abdul Hamid soon recognized that 'the blow to his reputation as suzerain was heavy ; and Mr. "Gladstone and Lord Salisbury having each pledged themselves again and again to leave Egypt, Sir Henry Drummond Wolff was sent to negotiate thin conditions on which British troops should withdraw A convention was agreed to. The last soldier was to be out of the county within seven years. Then a blunder way made, owing to external influences upon Yildiz, and the convention which Drummond Wolff had drawn, and which was accepted by the Grand Vizier and by England, was rejected by the Sultan. ..

"England had now just cause to be offended, and when & year or so later Abdul Hamid proposed that negotiations should be reopened on the basis of the Drummond Wolff Convention Lord Salisbury refused. From that time, or, to be more precise, from the time when France took possession of Tunis, no statesman of either party renewed the declaration that England would leave Egypt. Add to all this the facts that the enormous prosperity of Egypt has produced awkward comparisons with the backwardness of Turkey, that there is a large Druse and Moslem emigration from Syria into Egypt, and that many Turkish officials who were enrichin selves at the cost of the Egyptians have lost their means of plunder, and it will be seen that the irritation of Yildiz does not require the suggestion of Pan-Islamism. to explain its existence. | "It is said tha, Islamism during the last quarter of a century. has made many new converts, especially, indeed almost exclusively, in Central Africa. No one to my knowledge has ever suggested that the conversion of fetish worshippers to a belief in one God has been the result of missionary efforts from Turkey. But, assuming the statement to be true, it is far from showing either that there is a Pan-Islamic movement, or that such a movement is directed by. Abdul Hamid, Moslemismi being, liko Christianity, & great missionary religion, there is in it, and always has been, a movement for its propagation. Since the time of Mahomed it has constantly happened that its great and ennobling monotheistic teaching has appealed to uncivilized men. If more converts have been made of late than in preceding years, it is because the opening up of Africa has brought the black races into contact with Arab and other Moslem traders. In this limited sense there has been an increase in the number of Moslems. But to assert that this shows that there is a Pan-Islamic movement beyond the ordinary one which has been going on during centuries is unwarranted by the evidence.

"The massacre of Christians in Bulgaria and the unparalleled slaughter of Armenians are adduced as evidence of Pan-Islamism. As to the first, it took place before Abdul Hamid came to the throne. It must, therefore, be excluded as evidence against any such movement directed by him. He, however, must bear the reproach of the merciless slaughter of Armenians, and tho cruol persecution to which that pel ple has been subjected. But the outrages which all Europe justly condemned were not due to any Pan-Islamic movement. Though thousands were slaughtered by orders from Yildiz, the motive cannot be called reli. gious. The outrages were participated in by a Moslem population from motives mainly of plunder. The justification offered to the barbarians' who killed their neighbours and stole their property was that their intended victims were in revolt. The statement was in almost every case false. It was, of course, readily believed by people to whom it furnished & legal excuse for stealing all that they could lay their hands on. The motive was not so much religious or fanatical as mercenary. Moslems rarely, if ever, killed Armenians merely because they were Christians, but mostly to gain possession of what. those in authority told them they might take. Whatever were the motives which led to the Armenian massacres, and it is not difficult to find them, they do not give evidence of any Pan-İslamic movement.

"The construction of a railway to Mecca is adduced as one of the results of the Pan. Islamic movement. It is due in part, possibly altogether, to the initiative of Abdul Hamid. But anyone who knows what was the cost of the annual pilgrimage to Mecca, pilgrimage there being one of the "five pillars" of Islam and therefore obligatory, will marvel that such & trailway was not thought 6f long before. The marvel will be the greater when it is remembered that for fifty years Turkey has been constantly at war with Arab tribes. The only other evidence adduced in favour of Pan-Islamism is the attempt made in Afghanistan, and, perhaps, elsewhere, to lead the Moslems of those countries to make common cause with Turkey against Great Britain. Such attempts were undoubtedly made. In 1881 or 1882, when Lord Dufferin was here, he learned that a newspaper called Peik

Islam" was being printed at Yildiz for circulaItion in India during our troubles withi Afghanistan. Lord Dufferin was essentially a strong Ambassador, and he had a strong Liberal Government behind him. The representations made by him at Yildiz at once put a stop to all'attempts of that kind. It should be remem. bered that at the time there was very great soreness at Yildiz against England. The firmness of Mr. Goschen over the Dulcigno question was only one of several causes of such irritation. That an attempt was made to use the co-religionists of the Turks against us was not unnatural, but such attempt does not show the existence of a Pan-Islamic sentiment."

div.head: Embezzlement at Fashn.
div.p: It is reported from Fushn that Mastapha Effendi Ahmed, cashier of the markaz, disappeared from that town on the 27th olt., and that on the examination of his books and the cash it
Was found that L.E. 90 were missing. Mustapha's wife admitted that her husband bad had Bach a sum in his possession and that he took Et away with him when he left that morning.

div.head: Egyptian Ivory in London.
div.p: The extent and exceptionally fiae quality of the supply of Egyptian descriptions was the chief feature at the quarterly ivory sales held in London last week. Of the 63} tons on offer, 377 tons ware Egyptian (26) tons Alexandrian, 104 tons Malta descriptions), this being the largest supply offered for a considerable time past. The competition was general, soft large and medium tusks on the average advercing £8 to £15 per cwt., and hard £10 to £15 per cwt.

div.head: Repair of the Isla.
div.p: Messrs. Caird and Co, Greenock, who are shortly abdát to launch the Nore, the last of the four mail and passenger steamers for the Peninsular and Oriental Steam Navigation Company (the three already launched being the Nile, Namor, and the Nyanza), are about to put in band for extensive repair the same company's leis. It is understood that this steamship company will shortly invite tenders for the construction of five Jarge fast twin-screw mail steamers. The new vessels will be improvements on the Mongolia, which is of 9.500 tons gross register, and was built and engine - by Messrs. Caird in 1903.

div.head: London Koopeniok Case.
div.p: A rival of the captain of Koepenick appeared in the West London Police Court last week on & charge of obtaining money by false pretences. He gave his name as Edward Clarke, and described himself in court as an architect, bat Mr. George Bernett, who proge pated, said he had been posing for a long time 29 a retired colonel of the King's Rifles. He talked fluently on military.subjects, and described vividly his exploits in Egypt and the Sodan. When he met public men like the Mayor of Hammersmith in the street be Always greeted them with a military salute and said "Good morning," and they always Acknowledged the salate. Clarke, who admitted that he was not a colonel, declared that the money was given in payment for work he did For Mr. Barnett. He was committed for trial at the Old Bailey.

div.head:
UPPER NILE SURVEY.
GONDOKORO TO LAKE ALBERT.
div.p: Of the grant of L E. 15,000 for a levelled survey of the Nile from Gondokoro to Lake Albert nothing has yet been spent, but it is hoped that the work will be taken in hand this winter. The kendies of the Public Works Department for the several projects for controlling the Upper Nile are progressing with such rapidity that it seems probable that, in a year's time at most, it will be in a position to advise the Egyptian Government as to a definite selection from among them. Meanwhile the authorities have been much bandicapped by their lack of accurate knowledge regarding the levels of the river throughout its course, more especially from its sources to the second Cataract. Much has been done, and much is being done to rectify their ignorance in this respect. In Egypt proper, precision levelling is in progress. In the Cataract region, the survey parties above mentioned are at work, while, between Khartoam and Gondokoro, the officers of the Sudan Irrigation Service are carrying a line of levels up the White Nile and the Bohr-el-Gebel. South of Gondokoro,however, there is a complete blank, beyond the rough surveys of the river made by Sir William Garstin and others travellers. No levels exist and, beyond the information afforded by a certain number of barometric readings - avowedly inaccurate - we know nothing whatever regarding the slope and fall of the river. It is this portion of the Nile valley then that it is desired to have surveyed and levelled, at an early date.

Apart from the desirability of the work upon technical grounds-seeing that the construction of a regulator at the Albert lake may possibly be taken in hand simultaneously to the improvement of the channel in the swamps-such a survey is highly desirable upon a scientific grounds. Considering the importance of the Nile to Egypt and to the Sudan, the non-completion of such an undertaking must be held somewhat as a reproach to the administration of Public Works in Egypt.
The work will be commenced this winter. Levels will be carried across from the Victoria to the Albert lake, and thence down the Bahr-el-Gebel to Gondekoro.

As the water-level cf Lake Victoria has been a connected by spirit-levelling with the sea at Mombasa, we shall, when the chain is completed, have a complete circuit of levels from the Mediterranean-up the Nile valley and down the Uganda railway-to the Indian Ocean.

div.head:
MECCA PILGRIMAGE.
QUARANTINE RESTRICTIONS.
div.p: Mr. Morley, replying in the House of Commons on Thursday last to Ms. Rees, who asked whether the Turkish Government had agreed to the removal by the Government of India of the quarantine restrictions imposed at Bombay upon Mohammedan pilgrims to Mecca, said :-The quarantine regulations in question were imposed, and have been removed, by the Government of India on their own initiative and without previous reference to the Tarkish Government. They have been discontinued, as they were found to be supercious for the detection of plague while injurious to the comfort and health of the pilgrims. The Turkish Govərnment has been fully informed of these considerations, and of the precautionary measures which have been substituted for quarantide at Bombay.

div.head: BRITISH ENGINEERS IN EGYPT.
div.p: The Cairo correspondent of "African Engineering" says:- It is satisfactory to note that an increasing number of men are being brought out from home to fill official positions as engineers. This is, perhaps, a reason for the outcry which has lately been started in their
local Press about corruption in the Irrigation service. I would like to say at once that, amid so many temptations, a less corruptible body of men does not exist than the English official

in Egypt which is accounted for by Lord Cromer's care in selecting his men. Britons are notoriously the poorest men in Egypt, but the doings of the Levantine underlings in all branches of the public service, would well repay strict inquiry. The way in which numbers of them have grown rich while holding official positions is nothing short of marvellous, and their places might well be filled with Englishmen, to the advantage of the country and in the interests of true economy.

div.head: EGYPTIAN COTTON IN INDIA.
div.p: Apropos of the cultivation of Egyptian cotton in Sind, it appears on official authority, says the 'Capital" (Calcatta), that one of the principal difficulties the zemindar has to contend with is that of obtaining an adequate apply of labour for the cultivation of the staple. The ordinary labourer in Sind, it is said. dislikes the additional and unfamiliar trouble involved in the proper cultivation of Egyptian cotton. The zemindar is therefore hard put to secure efficient labour and has to pay well for it, and to take unwanted risks. The Bombay authorities have accordingly intimated to the Bombay mill industry that if they desire to see the Sind Egyptian cotton experiments accomplish the great results anticipated for them they must cooperate with Government in risking a little expenditure in money and effort in securing the crop and so encouraging the cultivator. A promising feature in the position is that the Bombay Government are hopeful of getting railway communication into the heart of the tract where Egyptian cotton is being grown in Sind at an fi early date.

div.head: THE SUCRERIES COMPANY..
div.p: The new management in Cairo of the Sacreries d'Egypte has advised the board in Paris of its success in effecting economies representing an annual saving of £400,000. A total output for the year of between 550,000 and 600,000 sacks is anticipated, which is calculated to produce a net profit of 5,000,000, this sum being sufficient not only to cover the interest on the mortgage bonds, ordinary debentures, and deferred shares, amounting to 4,500,00f. In all, but to leave & sum of 500,000f. for
distribution on the ordinary shares.

div.head: DEAN BUTCHER RETIRING.
div.p: We greatly regret to learn of the impending resignation of the Very Rev. Dean Batcher, D.D., who has held the chaplaincy of All Saints' Church, Cairo, for the past twenty-six years, during which period be has endeared himself
to the hearts of the English community. We Understand that Dean Batcher's health has,

of late, not been satisfactory and it is already known to our readers that he fell ill during his recent holiday in Switzerland. From this, we are glad to say, he has recovered, but he doubtless feels compelled to resign on account of his advanced years, which must prevent him from carrying on his work with that great zeal and energy, which he has amply demonstrated during his chaplaincy in Cairo. Dean Butcher came to Egypt from Shanghai, where he had ministered to the spiritual wants of the Angliean community since 1864, and previous to that he had held curacies at St. Clement's Danes and St. Paul's, Hammersmith. He is known to all of us as a deep scholar; he is a Fellow of the University of Durham, at which University he gained first class in classics. His writings, too, are well-known to all Anglo-Egyptians, the latest of which, "The Oriflamme in Egypt," he attracted a great many readers.

div.head: POULTRY CHOLERA.
div.p: The "Vérité" of Port Said calls the attention of the sanitary inspector of that town to the serious recrudescence of cholers among fowls, and advises the prohibition of the importation of fowls from Syria and Cyprus, as these on arrival in this country are frequently found to be diseased.
The other day Captain Moore, of the Port Suid police, made a tour of inspection through in the market and confiscated a considerable number of poultry suffering from cholera.

We might note that this disease has been prevalent in Egypt for more than a couple of years, and those upon whom have fallen the duties of housekeeping or catering long since discovered that it was only safe to accept poultry which was delivered to them alive Killed and dressed Egyptian fowl should never be accepted, as some doubt must remain as to what death was due to, and it is by no means uncommon for an animal to die from cholera between the purchaser's shop and the purchaser's house.

div.head: FAITH OF THE OLD EGYPTIANS
div.p: In the course of an interview in last week "Christian Commonwealth," Mr. H. Rider Hag on gard is reported as speaking as follows: "Mere negation and destructivism cannot possibly do any good to a race doomed to wander from darkness into darkness. Deprive man of the hope taught by all the creeds, and what is left, especially when he begins to grow old and has done with ambitions ?... The happiest people that the earth bag known were also the most absolute believers in the indefinite continuance of individual life. I mean the old Egyptians."

div.head: DENGUE FEVER PREVALENT
div.p: Dengue fever is very prevalent in the Keneh district, and nearly everybody in the town is suffering or has suffered from it in more or, less acute forms. There is also a certain amount of diphtheria.

div.head: S.P.C.A. Branch.
div.p: Than to the initiative taken by Mr. Å. W. Hazell, inspector in the Ministry of the Interior, and Mr. C. W. Warner, of the Agricultural Bank,a local branch of the S.P.C.A. has been established here. Mr. Hazell and Mr. Warner were ably seconded by the sub mandir, Abdul Halim Bey. A meeting was held at the moudirieh this morning and the appeals of Mr. Hazell apd Abdul Halim Bey were liberally responded to, L.E. 275 being handed over to the treasurer. A hospital for animals is to be built behind the Post Office:

div.head: National Bank.
div.p: An agency of the National Bank of Egypt is than to be opened on the 15th inst. at Luxor, of which Mr. Bernard Losco has been appointed that manager.

div.head: Water Supply
div.p: It is more than a year ago since money was granted to the municipality for the extension

To that of the town's water installation, and yet there are no signs of the work being commenced. Much dissatisfaction is expressed at the procrastinating methods of the municipality, and the inhabitants are hoping that the Ministry of the Interior will take the matter up when their attention is drawn to it by this protest

div.head: TELEPHONES IN EGYPT.
div.p: ALEXANDRIA.COMES FIRST. ;

In Sir William Garstin's report for 1905 there are some interesting figures showing the number of subscribers to the Telephone Company and the capacity of the boards in the various towns in which the service exists.
It is somewhat curious that Alexandria, ed to lo

lor whose population is considerably less than that of Cairo, should have 216 more subscribers than the capital. The capacity of the Alexandria board, too, only provides for another 96 subscribers, whereas the Cairo board can accommodate 412 extra pegs. Port Said subscribers only number 177, Tantah has 112, and Suez 88.
There are in all 4,243 subscribers, of which Alexandria's share amounts to 1,924, and the
number of calls through the exchange averages ending 12 calls per subscriber per day, or about 50,916 calls over the entire system.

div.head: WRESTLING AT CAIRO
div.p: Tuesday night's wrestling matches at the Theatre Abbas, Cairo, were decidedly interesting. The second bout between Schakmann and Limonsin was the event of the evening. It terminated in the overthrow of the former after half an hour's very keen and vigorous struggle. Van der Berg beat Noël after 15 minutes' good wrestling.

We notice that "Al Moayad" blames the crowd of spectators for their excessive partisanship. Our confrère's sporting contributor seizes the occasion to deplore the absence of athletics from Egyptian life, remarking that the Greek (sic) adage, "a sound mind in a healthy body," is not sufficiently regarded in Egypt.

div.head: EGYPTIAN GOlD DEMAND.
div.p: THE COUNTRY'S MARVELLOUS.
PROSPERITY.

The large withdrawals of gold from the Bank of England for Egypt have formed an import ant topic for discussion in the London financial Press during the past few weeks. In a recent article on the subject, the "Financier" gives the following able statement of the facts regarding the position :--
The only trouble in Egypt, financially, is the rapidly growing prosperity of the country.

In connection with the recent large withdrawals of gold from the Bank of England on Egyptian account there has been some apprehension that more of the metal might have to go the same way--even large amounts--and that, consequently, more stringent conditions than ever might supervere in the London money market. As the result of enquiries in banking-circles connected with Egypt it may be said that, although further remittances of gold to that country may have to be made, it is not very likely that they will aggregate more than three-quarters of a million sterling, or, at the outside, a million. Also it does not follow that the whole of this will be drawn from England. France, having, actually and relatively, a much larger supply of gold available than the United Kingdom, could, if need be, send it to Egypt with less effort. It is not expected that this will happen on a large scale, but it is probable there will be some consignments from that quarter.

A representative of the "Financier," in the course of several interviews with banking authorities, elicited an interesting exposé of the situation with respect to the need for gold in Egypt in relation to the cotton crop One gentleman, whose description of the true position of affairs may be taken as typical, said:-

"There has been, seemingly, quite a mistaken idea as to the meaning of those consignments of gold to Egypt. Some financial writers appear to be in ignorance of the fact that every year at this season large consignments of gold are made to Cairo, mainly in connection with the cotton crop. It is so expected and so regular an operation that it usually excites the very slightest notice. This time, however, for two or three reasons, it has been made very conspicuous. It happened that the gold was withdrawn at such a moment and in such a way that it was associated with the declaration of a 6 per cent. Bank rate. And the total amount withdrawn up to date is more than it has been hitherto.
"There are several reasons for this, but there are two in particular, The Egyptian

cotton crop this year is a very big one, estimated at seven millions of cantars. Consequently that fact alone would mean more money-more gold brought into the cöntry, to pay for it - than has been the case hitherto. Then there was the partial destruction of the cotton crop in the United States. It is impossible to say even now what the approximate damage really amounted to. The bull operators of course made the most of their opportunity and put up prices as high as possible, but the damage was severe, and there will be a certain shortage; consequently a rise in the price of cotton is a legitimate result. The quotations for Egyptian cotton have been
considerably affected, so that not only shall we have a very large output, but a higher price for the product. This will mean a larger amount of gold than heretofore to 'lift' the crop.

"In those circumstances it requires no argument to show that Egypt will, during the next twelve months, be in a position to make perhaps greater progress than she has ever done before in any one year. At any rate, she will be exceedingly prosperous, and that property will, naturally, have a certain stimulating effect in this country."
"May I ask if you can tell me how it was that the Bank of England appeared not to be aware of these requirements of Egypt until, as it were, the last moment.?"

"I suppose that the management do not or in this case did not take sufficient cognisance of what was going on in the outside financial world beyond what was communicated to them officially. If they had possessed the knowledge it is to be surmised they would have put up the rate 5 per cent. some weeks ago. That would have been far better from every point of view, and would have avoided the equeeze which has been brought about by the 6 percent. rate-an abnormal one which, it is to be hoped, will not last very long."
"Do you consider it probable that the success of this season's cotton crop in Egypt will - stimulate the planting of a large acreage ?"
"Yes; I should say it certainly will."
"May there not be a consequent slump in the price for the 1907 orop ?"

"It by no means follow. At present the fine | long staple cotton grown in Egypt cannot be raised successfully in any other country in the world. And I believe the demand for it is steadily growing. Not only in Europe, but in the United States, Egyptian cotton is being used in constantly increasing quantities.".
"If the price were reduced, do you think the consumption would be much increased?

"I doubt it. But at present there appears to be no need to reduce the price. There are, of course, different qualities of the fibre produced in Egypt, but the best appears it be always sure of a market. In the Sadat there is a certain small quantity of short staple cotton grown, more like iho American variety but I do not know whether it is exported a all; the entire quantity raised is very trifling I am not an expert on cotton, but I understand the cultivators consider the soil and climate of Egypt particularly adapted for the long staple description, and as this is always likely to command the higher price there can be little

doubt that it is the variety which will be planted as fresh ground is broken. Personally, I look forward to the indefinite development of Egypt for many years to come, and to the employment of vast sums of English money there for beyond anything which has yet been done. The exports of our gold to Cairo should be regarded As a matter for congratulation.

div.head: PERSONAL AND SOCIAL.
div.p: Prince Ibrahim Pasha Hilmy, uncle of the Khedive, has purchased at Pausilippo the Villa Rendel, a magnificent structure overlooking the bay of Naples and situated in a beautiful part close to the sea. His Highness intends to pass the winter there.

The Ministers and Sir Vincent Corbett, the Financial Adviser, are coming down to Alexandria tomorrow, and will be granted an audience by the Khedive at Ras el Tin Palace. After obtaining his Highness's sanction to Various schemes, the officials will return to Cairo in the evening.
The Countess of Cromer left Marseilles last Wednesday for Port Said by the Bibby liner Derbyshire and arrived at Cairo late last night. We are glad to say that the Countess is in excellent health.
Lady Gorst is arriving at Port Said shortly. by the P. &0. S.S. Macedonia on a visit to Egypt.

Mr. Maneteld de C. Findlsy, Councillor of the British Agency in Cairo, had the honour of being received by the King at Buckingham Palace yesterday week Curiously enough, in the Court Circular announcement of the audience, the Agency is described as "his Majesty's Embassy."
Sir Aogastus Hemming and Lady and Miss Hemming are leaving London for Egypt about the middle of the month.

Dr. Porphyrios Logothetis, the Archbishopof Mount Sinai, the famous monastery renowned for its precious and unique manuscripts, is now in Paris on his way to England. After paying a short visit to London he will go to Cambridge, where the degree of D.D.L. was conferred on him two years ago.
Macauley Bey returned to Cairo yesterday..
Dr. Graham has returned from Europe.
Kaimakam Ali Bey Ismail has been appointed commandant of the Khedivial Body Guard - ice Abdallab Bey Fikri, transferred to the
Meieb.
Abdel Khalih Bsy Sarwat has been appointed director of administration to the Ministry of Justice.

We regret to announce the impending retirement of Mr. P. P. Graves, our Cairo Correspondent, from the staff of the "Egyptian Gazette." Mr. Graves has accepted an important correspondentship on the staff of the London "Times."
M. Shakri Ghanem, the author of 'Antar," has returned.

St. Andrew's Church, Alexandris, on Tuesday, the marriage took place of Mr. Thomas Hood, F.S.I., resident manager of the Gharbieh Land Co. Ris el-Khalig, to Miss Mary Todd Wilson, daughter of the late John Wilson, of Edington, Mains, Dons. The Rev. H. P. Reid officiated.
Mr. A Paulkner, the chief accountant in ce London of Messrs. Thos. Cook & Son, arrived in Cairo from England last night.

Amongst the latest arrivals at the Eastern Exchange Hotel, Port Said, are : Miss A. Eyre, Mr. and Mrs. F. W. Sykes, Mr. and Mrs. Psycha, Mr. G. H. Sharmap, Mr. G. B. Ireland, Mr. E. C. Pennefather, Mr. H. Boyd Carpenter, Mr. M. C. Stubbs, Mr. Etohogoyeao, Mr. M. E. Bandmann and party, Mr. J. F. G. Hopkins, Mr. K.C. Hopkins, Mr. D. / Lawson, Rev. H. G. div.head: COMMISSION MUNICIPALE
div.p: (Communication Officielle)
La Commission Municipale s'est réunie le 7 novembre 1906 à 9 heures da soir sous la présidence de 8.B. le Docteur Sobies Pacha.
Mention est faite de l'envoi à tons les membres des procès-verbaux des séances de 18 Délégation des 2, 16, 23 et 30 octobre 1906.

A l'occasion de cette communication, M. Stross ayant demandé où en était la question de la nomination d'un nouvel ingénieur en chef, le Président répond que l'administration a été chargée de dresser un relevé des états de servic; des divers concurrents, afin de le distri. buer aux membres de la Commission, préalablement à la décision qui sera prise à une pro. chaine séance.

A la enite d'ane observation de Mr. Rieti relativement aux exemptions gracieuses de la taxe sur les bestiaux et véhicules dont bénéficient divers contribuables et particulièrement les établissements de bienfaisance ou d'instruction, la Commission considérant que les décisions, à prendre sur les remises gracieuses de cette, datare lui incombent, demande à la Délégation une nouvelle étude et des propositions.

M. Benachi relève une correspondance échangée avec la Société des Tramways au sujet de l'adaptation aux voitures de tramways de chesse corps destinés à prévenir les accidents ; il demande que la Municipalité insiste de la manière la plus énergique auprès de la Société pour qu'on arrive enfin à une solution de cette question qui traîne depuis longtemps.
L'assemblés, adopte.
Communication est donnée :

1° D'une lettre de S. B. le Ministre de l'Intérieur da 10 Octobre 1906 informant qu'étant, donné la grande importance que présente la question du transfert projeté des échèches du Gabbari et autres, il y aurait lien que la Municipalité se livre a une étude détaillée et complète de la question avant de la soumettre à nouveau af Ministère:
A ce sujet et sar la proposition de la Délégation, la Commission autorise l'engagement
à titre provisoirs pour la durée de six mois d'un ingénient pour le relevé des localités que
le projet intéresse, ainsi que celui de echèches et entreprendre toutes études préparatoires ao transfert.
2° d'une lettre de S.E. le Ministre de l'Inté. rieur da 13 Octobre 1906 approuvant les cré. dits votés par la Commission le 3 Octobre 1906.

3. d'une lettre de S.E. le Ministre de l'Inté. rieur du 17 Octobre 1906 remettant un rapport et des plans dressés par le Ministère des Travaux Publics concernant les détails et renseignements nécessaires au sujet du projet de construction et de réfection de trois ponts sur le canal Mahmoudieh.
L'Administrateur rappelle que le Gouvernement a promis de contribuer à ce travail promis L. E. 6,COO, le restant, soit 12,500 LE devant être supporté par la Municipalité, qui a
fait appel aux contributions des Associations et Sociétés intéressées : le Ministère a,en outre
sur la prière de la Commission, dressé les plans et devis des dits ouvrages.

Divers membres font ressortir la gêne constante que cause commerce l'état actuel du pont Ibrahim, et demandent que sa réfection soit faite d'urgence et que dès passerellessoient installées provisoirement afin d'assurer les communications pendant les travaux.

D'autres membres estiment al contraire qu'on devrait commencer par la construction des deux autres ponts, ceux-ci devant permettre d'alléger le trafic intense qui existe sur le pont Ibrahim, en attendant sa réfection.
Sur la demande de l'administrateur, il 680 décidé de s'en remettre au Ministère des
Travaux Publics qui appréciera quel est le mode d'exécution le plus favorable au point de vue des intérêts du commerce, de la circulation, et de la mise en ceuvre des travaux.
La dépense incombant la Municipalité, saut restitution d'ane partie par les associations intéressées, sera prélevé sur le produit de la vente des biens.
4 d'une lettre de S.E. le Ministre de l'intérieur du 25 octobre 1906 approuvant le règlement relatif si transport des matières pouvant dégager de la poussière ou de mauvaises odeurs.
(à suivre).

div.head: BULLETIN DE LA BOURSE
div.p: (Aujourd'hui à midi et demie.)

Le marché a débuté complètement déprimé sous les offres constantes des, vendeurs. En clôture, cependant, il y a eu relèvement partiel à la suite d'une demande provenant du Caire. On croit généralement qu'une reprise est imminente.

Les affaires n'ont eu d'importance qu'en Delta Land et Bitates, mais l'animation > gagné par la fin les Hocker, la Salt & foda, l'Urbaine et l'Union Foncière. Il y a eu également que' ques affaires en Cassa di Sconto et Alexandria Water.

De 1 5/82 les Hooker s'avancent & 1 la Delta Land de 4 1/32 à 4 3/32, les Estates do 2 1/4 à 2 932, l'Union Foncière de 6 7/16 à 6 15/82, l'Alexandria Water de 13 13/16 13 7/8 et la Cassa di sconto de 240 1/2.241 l'ancienne et de 235 1/2 à 236 la nouvelle.

En hausse également la Privilégiée Tramways de 187 1/2 à 188, 164 Cotton Mills de 13 # 7/6, l'Obligation nouvelle Cré lit Foncier de 271 à 271 1/2, les Lots Turcs de 151 à 152, et les Splendid Hotels de 4 1/32 à 4 1/16.

Par contre, la Dsira fruit en réaction de 17 1/4 à 17 1/16, la Béhéra de 43 1/2 à 43, la Bière d'Alexandria de 215 à 210 la Privilégiée et de 124 $ 120 la Dividende, la Bière da Caire de 136 à 134 la Privilégiée et de 77 á 75 la Dividende, la Banque d'A hère de 147 A 116, les Nangovich Hotels de 18 8/16
18 18 10 dinary Khedivial Mail de 39 å 38/9, l'Investment de 1 9/32 à 1 1/4 vendeure, la part de fondateur Comptoir de 53 à 52, et le Crédit Franco-Égyptien de 512 À 5 7/16.
Au sujet de la prolongation par le Comité de la bourse du Caire de délai accordé aux ingénieurs architectes pour présenter leurs dessins, le Journal du Caire écrit :

Il s'agit ici d'une très importante question Le nouveau palais de la Bourne da Caire devra etre bâti sur les plans les meilleurs. On n'aura donc jamais trop de concurrents. Il importe peu que quelques intérêts privés soient lésés quand il s'agit de l'intérêt de toute une corporation. Car il ne faut pas que les agents de change aient à se repentir un jour d'avoir fait un choix trop rapide parmi les dessins d'un nombre trop restreint de concurrents. Nous ne dontons pas que nos confrères de reconnaissent la justesse de nos observations.

div.head: Circulaire H. De Vries et Boutigny
div.p: NOTES ET CRITIQUES

Le Caire, 7 Novembre 1906. Le taux de l'escompte libré à Londres est toujours renseigné à 6 0/0. Hier, aq Stock Exchange, le Consolidé anglais a baissé de 1/8 à 86 3/8. L'Unifiée est restée invariée à 102 174. La National Bank & rétrograde de 1/8 & 27 1/1,, de même que la Daïra à 17 1/4 et la Delta Light à 12 1/8. L'Agricole est demeurée inchangée à 9 7/8.
A Paris, l'action Crédit Foncier Egyptien & avancé à 783. La Banque d'Athènes s'est maintenue à 118.

Ici, la séance d'aujourd'hui a été plus ou moins la reproduction de celle d'hier: matinée - calme et lourde. L'offre a encore dominé la demande. La baisse du coton, la faiblesse des places dirigeantes d'Occident et la persistance de la tension monétaire continuent visiblement

à exercer leur effet sur le marché. Mais encore y a-t-il lieu de constater que la dépression s'est arrêtée sur plusieurs valeurs par saite des achats déterminés par les bag cours pratiques; ce qui est un indice de bon augure.

Dans le compartiment des Banques, la National, très mouvementée, a' fléchi à 27 3/16 pour remonter à 27 1/4 et clôturer aux abords de ce dernier prix. L'Agricole a molli à 9 11/16. La Cassa di Sconto a faibli à 241 et la Banque d'Athènes à 146. Le Comptoir Financier & perda 5/32 à 6 7/8-15/16 ; la part de fondateur est revenue à 52.
Le Crédit Foncier est resté à 780. La Daïra a fléchi à 17-17 1/16. L: Béhéra a été cotée 43-43 1/4. L'Union Foncière a fléchi à 6 3/8 pour finir à 6 7/16-1/2.
L'Immobilière & fléchi & 380, et sa part de fondateur à 720. La part de fondateur Agricole da Nil a baissé à 9 1/1. La Nile Land a perda 3/8 & 17 1/8. Le Wardan Estate s'est alourdi à 77/16.
Tres malmenés, malgré une rumeur suivant laquelle leur dividende serait de P.R. 60, les Improvements ont été ramenés à 6 1/4, perdant 1/4 de livre.
L'action Entreprises Immobilières et Travaux s'est raffermie à 4 1/2 ; la part de fonda
teur a clôturé à 89-90.
Les Allotments se sont tassés à 3 15/16-4 et leur part de fondateur à 158.

La Delta Light & baissé de 1/16 à 12. Les Automobiles ont décliné jusqu'à 5 5/8 pour remonter à 5.13/16 et finir à 5 3/4 ; lear part de fondateur & perda 1/18 9 3/4. Les Jouissances Elux du Caire ont olótoré à 267 et les Frigorifiques à 49/16. La Merevleh & réactionné à 3 7/8.
Dans le groupe des valeurs hôtelières, les Nangovich ont faibli à 18-18 1/16, les Egyptian & 7 3/8-7/16, les Upper Egypt å 5 5/16 3/8 et les National à 4.

Parmi les petites valeurs, les Delta Land se sont raffermis à 4 1/16, les Hooker à 1 3/16 et i les Estates à 2 1/4-5, 16. Les Markets sont revenus à 26,9, les New Egyptian à 32/9, les Salt and Soda à 24/, les Abdy à , 1 1/4, la Khedivial Mail à 39/, les Walker and Meimarachi : 0 11/16, les Cotton Mills à 7/8 et le Cold Storage à 01/2. Les Sucreries ont réactionné à 28 francs.
Si nog informations sont exactes, la nouvelle émission de la Cassa di Sconto e di Risparmio aurait lieu en Janvier prochain et non en Mai od en Avril, comme cela avait été dit précé demment.
-Le capital de serait porté qu'à 15 millions de francs en lien de 20 millions. Chaque deux actions anciennes auraient droit à une nouvelle, au prix de 150 francs.
Les recettes des Egyptian Markets pour la semaine au 18 Octobre ont été de L. B. 516 contre 387 en 1905, soit en augmentation de LE. 128.
L38 recettes totales depuis le 1er Janvier 1906 ont atteint la somme de L E. 27,246 contre 20,461 en 1901, soit en plus.value de L.E. 6,785..

div.head:
WHOLE BATTALION DISMISSED.
DISARMING OF AMERICAN NEGROES

div.p: President Roosevelt has dismissed the whole 98th Negro Battalion for refusing to disclose the culprits in the case of the rioting in Brownsville (Texas), in August, 1905, which resulted in a citizen being killed.. It has been decided to disarm all negroes employed in the Army and Navy in a civilian capacity.(Reuter)

div.head: GREEK AND ANGLICAN CHURCHES.
div.p: THE QUESTION OF REUNION.

For the past five weeks the Very Roy. Archimandrite H.A. Teknopoulos, who went to Eng. land with the blessing of the Patriarch of ConBtantinople, to promote reunion between the Anglican and Orthodox - Eastern Churches, has been delivering a course of lectures upon the leading doctrinal and ceremonial points at 188de in St. Alban's Hall, Holborn. The Archimandrite, who is, like most Greek ecclesiastica, of picturesque personal appearance, hss acquired creditable command of English during his sojourn in London, and his addresses, delivered with surprising fluency and fervour, have attracted crowded audiences, among whom the feminine element has largely predominated.

His concluding lecture was given last week upon the subject of the nature and authority of "The Church," from an "Orthodox" stand. point, and advantage was taken of the opportunity by his hearers to present him with a token of their appreciation in the shaj e of a costly silver paten and chalice.

As å result of his researches, Pather Teknopoulos has arrived at the conclusion that the "heresies' ' and defects of which the Anglican Church has been accused by her Eastern sister have been introduced from outside," and are neither fundamental nor inherent. Efforts for the reunion of the Anglican and Eastern Churches have been made spasmodically ever since the days of the Nop-Jarors, but the problem has bitberto beeå left in the otio e tands of dilettanti and academic High Churchmen.

The real significance of the present development to keen observers is that the matter bag now has been taken up by the clergy of St. Alban's, Holborn, who were once described by Archbishop Temple ss "very astute people," who work without talking, and who never meddle with any movement unless it seems likely to lead to some practical result

div.head: MONEY AND SHARE MARKET
div.p: (FROM FINANCIAL CORRESPONDENT.)
London, November 2.
The Money Market.

The action of Mr. Shaw in withdrawing the facilities previously given' for importing gold from abroad and allowing the depositary banks to substitute 18 million dollars of approved securities, thug freeing note circulation that amount, comes rather late, but is an indication that he reali-es the folly of allowing foreign markets to be unnecessarily disturbed. The effect of his dilatory methods has already produced sufficient disturbance, and prevent the renewal of large blocks of American bil for which the Trans-Atlantio banks will now have to provide. Mr. Shaw is, it is understood intending to press' new currency legislation make the note circulation more 'elastic. F. the moment no fears arise from America further demands for gold, and it is to Egypt that all eyes are turned, and the further amount required to meet the demand consequently on the moving of the crops is free discussed. So far this week & further £135,00 has been withdrawn for that market from the Bank of England, and the general opinion, that farther sama will be wanted before Egypt requirements are fully met. South America is also a likely buyer of gold. On the other hand the Bank has received £455,000, and the general position is more favourable than anticipated. The decline in the reserve is on £30,000, and the proportion of cash to liabilities is 364 per cent. The outside market i however, former at i to 6 per cent. for bes paper, The Bank rate is now thoroughly èffective, and consequently the Bank of England have full control of the money market and are able to obtain incoming gold whenever they want it. The general opinion as to t fatore is that the present rate of 6 per cent will remain in force for some months, and that it is highly improbable that the Bap directors will find it necessary to put the rat any higher. From information gathered from the best sources we are of opinion, therefore that we must look for a 6 per cent. rate until well after the turn of the year, and that i will probably be the middle of February before we shall see this lowered. .

The joint stock banks are being mool criticised for not having larger reserves C bullion, and the present stringency is po doab to some extent due to their not taking the advice of the best money authorities repeatedly given to them to do so.
Silver.
Silver 'is harder at 32 The Stock Markets. ,

Members of the Stock Exchange are.com sistent observers of holidays, and as by a law passed far back in the history of the Institution the first of November has always been recognised as a Stock Exchange festival, consequently the House" was closed yesterday when some of the more athletic members availed themselves of this opportunity to get rid o ooperfiaque energy by the king & midnight stroll" to Brighton.i

This suspension of business on a Thursday of all day', has of course seriously interfered with the week's operations. Fortunately, the improvement in the money position, and the prospects of an early return to normal conditions, had reduced to a minimum the fears at one time prevalent in some quarters, that the Bank rate might be again raised, and s dealers left town with an easy mind on this score. This returning optimism regarding the money situation was responsible for the good tone in the stock markets during the early part of the week, and although Consols were somewhat depressed by the stiff contant rates charged by the banks, most other sections were cheerful.
To-day markets opened steady after the holiday, but little business has been transacter -ap to the time of writing. The general tone however, may be called fairly good.
Consols.

The carry-over in Consols this week was marked by the severe rate which were charged, bankers demanding 6 to 64 per cent. against an average of 45 per cent. & monti ago. Tko gilt-edged market in the main ha kept steady, but Consol, have been inclined to Fag somewhat, probably onder the influencé o these high contangoes. After the carry-over on Wednesday they closed down at 86 for cash and 86 ⅜ for the new account. The cash price to-night is 86 1/8, and the account 86 1/2.
Foreign Bonds.

The great activity of Rashian securities has again been an interesting feature of the foreign market.'Up to the Hooge closing on Wednesday the Siript of the new Fives has beer redaced to 35. á rise on the day of 15, and the Foars had improved to 76. The closing quotations to day are 6% discount ex dividend, and the Foor: 76.

It is stated in well-informed quarters that i good deal of the recent buying of the bonds ba been on behalf of Jewish operators, and this i significant in view of the reforms said to bay Teen promised by the Russian Government il the matter if the treatment of the Jews il Roix.
Japanese have not been so bacyant, and quotations are rather lower on balance.
Home Rails.

The demand for these shares, which gave an appearance of activity to this market last week has subsided, and greatness, almost idleness Dow prevails. North Westerns, which bar gained substantially in price during the sbor -evival, have decliprd to 1507. South Westeri D ferred to 468, and Great Central to 165. In most other cases the movements have beer downward. Today the market has been irregular, and declines have been general.

The traffic, returns are favorable, gains being recorded in nearly every instance. The North Western report an increase of £2,000, while last year the company had a gain of £17,000. The Great Western add £9,700 to last year's increase of £5,900.
Americans.

The American section has been moderately cheerful, although the disappointment experienced in conreation with the Steel Corporation's dividend cansed a set-back on Wednesday. Under this influence Steel Common relapsed to 48 They close to.light at 49.

American railways opened depressed today, Chesapeakes fell 3, and several of the other shares ¼ to 1/2 . Pennsylvania were, however, a good point, and advanced while Reading also gained 1. The general tone towards the close was better, however.
There was a substantial revival in Mexican rails on Wednesday, the Fours spurting 4 to 88, and two or three of the others 3 to 3 1/2.
Egyptians,

Egyptian stocks and shares are now beginning to receive marked attention and the revival which we announced two or three weeks ago continues to grow in extent. This week there has been a good demand for several of the Egyptian shares, which has to-day considerably increased. A notable feature of the week has been the renewal of activity in Daira Sanieh. These have been idle for a long time past, and the quotations have continued in the region of 16 ¾ 7/8. They have now advanced to 17 3/8 buyers, and give promise of going still higher. The Deferred, however, still remains about 97. Khedivial Mail have been a strong market at 378. 63. bid, but there are no e hyres on offer. National Bank of Egypt have been as good as 27%, or higher than our last quotation. The demand for these has fallen off somewhat now, and the close is lower at 27). Agricultural Banks are firmer, and there are several bayers at 9. Delta Preference Bearer are wanted at 12), which shows & rise of about . while Delta Land & Investment are asked for at 11 Egyptian Estates are quiet but firm, the prices being well maintained at 2, the Deferred at 15$ with no selling. Union Foncière are better at 68, but Land Bank of Bgypt are ancbanged at 9g. Bank of Abyssinia are practically dead at it discount pominal. Corporation of Western Egypt remain dall at premium. Last week New Egyptians were an active point, but the market for these shares has eased off, and the price closes quiet bat firm at 15-1. Daira Sogar áre 2$, while there is no mention of Bank of Romania at 10.
Mining

The South African market has a bright appearance, and during part of the week was quite active. Modders, on Wednesday advanced 3 to 5 t, and Geduld and East Rands were respectively 7/32 and 5/32 higher. New Vaal River were in a very excited state on Monday. After opening at 103, they rose rapidly to 12, but with the advent of bear sellers dropped equally rapidly and closed at 9. They are now 61, having dropped a farther 27 today. Mining shares are good in tone to-day. Geduld has advanced , and several others 1/16 to 1/8.

In the Egyptian section Nile Valley Block "E" have been a satisfactory feature. These shares, which we quoted at in our last article, advanced early in the work to 1, at which they closed steady before the holiday. They leave off to night at H. There are no other changes, quotations being quietly firm.

div.head: CAUSE OF CANCER
div.p: WARNING TO INVETERATE SMOKERS.

At the last sitting of the French Academy of Medicine, Professor Poirier, in the course of some interesting remarks regarding cancer of the tongue, said it was confined to two classes of people, one of them being inveterate smokers. Cancer of the tongue was the most dangerous form of the disease, yet it was corable if the Bargeon took it in time, practising wide incisions in the tongue. Of thirty two patients operated on by the Professor for cancer of the tongue, seven died from the results of the operation, eleven quick became worse, five were operated on & second time, and of the five two seemed to be cured, the operations in their cases dating thirteen months ago. Every one of the thirty-two, added the Professor, was & smoker, and twenty-seven of the thirty-two had suffered or were then suffering from a contagious disease.

div.head: THRONE OF TURKEY.
div.p: The Corriere della Sera" bas received from its Constantinople correspondent a statement that the Sultan is much weakened, owing to the pain caused by his illness. The correspondent declares that, although the Salt an eagerly wishes to modify the order of the succession to the Throne, and to appoint as heir his son Barbaneddin Effendi, his brother, Reshad Effendi, nevertheless will succeed him. Reehad is sixty years old, and is now living in coufioemopt, under striot guard. Like his father, Burhaneddin is a warm friend to Germany, who encourages the spread of opinion favorable to his 8 ccassion, but he has always been strongly opposed by the Old Turkish party.

div.head: AVIS :
div.p: Il est porté à la connaissance da public que la Société Egyptienne Tewfikieh et le Sieur Andraons Bichara mettent aux enchères pobliqueb la location de leur Grand Hotel his à Looxor poor, la saison, d'hiver 1906 07 com me çant le 1er décembre 1906.

Les personnes qui sont désireuses de louer le dit hôtel sont priées d'adresser leurs offres : - 1) aux liquidateurs de la Socié é Egyptienne Tewfikieh en la personne da : 1. Kamel Bay Toymour, 2. Ahmed Bay Khouloussi.
2.) & Mr. Andraoag Bichara.
Les demandes doivent être adrersé 38 jnsqui'an :0 courant aq Bureau de Ahmed bey | Kboalou-ei, wis Rond-Point Sulimon Pacha, Immeuble Ayrcot.
